conclusion: To determine the height H above the ground at which the fire extinguishing projectile hits the high-rise building, we need to analyze the projectile motion in both the horizontal and vertical directions.
The initial velocity v0 is given as 50 m/s at an angle θ = 53°.
The horizontal component of the initial velocity v0x is v0x = v0 cos θ = 50 cos 53° = 30 m/s.
The vertical component of the initial velocity v0y is v0y = v0 sin θ = 50 sin 53° = 40 m/s.
The horizontal distance L is given as 60 m.
Since there is no horizontal acceleration, the horizontal distance covered by the projectile is given by L = v0x t. Solving for time t: t = L / v0x = 60 / 30 = 2 s.
The acceleration due to gravity g is 10 m/s².

premise: v0y = 40 m/s, t = 2 s, g = 10 m/s²
conclusion: The vertical displacement y after time t under constant acceleration due to gravity g is given by y = v0y t - (1/2) g t². Substituting the known values: y = 40 × 2 - (1/2) × 10 × 2² = 80 - 20 = 60 m.
The height H above the ground at which the fire extinguishing projectile hits the high-rise building is 60 m.
